items.title: Ontario mobile homeowners struggling to sell properties accuse park owner of using tactics that break the law
items.summary_auto: Some homeowners and Realtors are accusing a private equity firm that owns mobile home parks in Ontario of using questionable and illegal tactics to raise lot rents beyond what many can afford. As a result, they say, homes that have traditionally been seen as affordable are becoming nearly impossible to sell.

items.title: Did removal of N.B.’s front licence plates make solving crimes harder?
items.summary_auto: Recent thefts raise a question about the effectiveness of removing front licence plates.

items.title: Members of 99-year-old Halifax legion want answers as branch set to close
items.summary_auto: The 99-year-old Vimy branch in Halifax has been struggling financially since it lost its lottery licence last year after its former vice-president pocketed more than $25,000 from Chase the Ace draws.

items.title: Remote First Nation in Ontario 'in a dire situation' over unclean water, wants military to help get people out
items.summary_auto: Frustrations are mounting in a remote First Nation in northern Ontario amid plans to evacuate residents due to a lack of clean water. Now, Kashechewan is asking Ottawa for military help to get people out of the community, which had been relying on bottled water and snowmelt after the treatment plant failed.

items.title: The Canada Reads 2026 longlist is here
items.summary_auto: This year, the great Canadian book debate is looking for one book to build bridges. The panellists and the books they choose to champion will be revealed on Jan. 22.

items.title: Thousands of Quebec children with disabilities kept out of school due to lack of resources
items.summary_auto: Thousands of students with disabilities across the province are experiencing a “break in services” because of a lack of resources. There were nearly 1,500 students in 2021. By 2025, it had climbed to more than 3,400 students.

items.title: Heated Rivalry's Shane is autistic. If you didn't notice, that's the point
items.summary_auto: Rachel Reid, the Canadian author behind the Game Changer book series that inspired the show, has previously confirmed on Reddit that Shane is "probably autistic" — though she didn't set out to write him as such. However, she said she doubted he'd "ever realize it himself."

items.title: Why aren't at-home HPV tests readily available in Canada?
items.summary_auto: The U.S. Health Resources and Services Administration issued new recommendations on Monday that will eventually allow women and people assigned female at birth easier access to at-home self-testing kits for the human papilloma virus (HPV), which is sexually-transmitted and can cause cervical cancer.

items.title: Kashechewan First Nation in northern Ont. wants military to help evacuate residents over lack of clean water
items.summary_auto: Frustrations are mounting in a remote First Nation in northern Ontario amid plans to evacuate residents due to a lack of clean water. Now, Kashechewan is asking Ottawa for military help to get people out of the community, which had been relying on bottled water and snowmelt after the treatment plant failed.

items.title: This 'spectacle' of a snowman is so big his nose is a traffic cone
items.summary_auto: A massive snowman stands guard over a quiet street in Ottawa's Alta Vista neighbourhood. Hallie Cotnam dropped by to meet Stan and his creators.

items.title: Despite wanting Maduro in prison, this Venezuelan-Canadian professor isn't celebrating U.S. intervention
items.summary_auto: McMaster University philosophy professor says the U.S. capture of Nicolás Maduro puts Venezuelans in a 'very dangerous' political situation, while another Venezuelan in Hamilton says she sees the move as a chance for positive change.

items.title: With Trump's Venezuela move and Greenland threats, are Canadians vulnerable?
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump's increasingly bellicose stance on taking over Greenland, on the heels of capturing Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro, have combined to trigger questions about what the White House has in mind for Canada.

items.title: Some Greenlanders express outrage over Trump's threats. But not all are concerned
items.summary_auto: Many Greenlanders are expressing their anger and frustration over U.S. President Donald Trump's recent musings that the United States needs to acquire their island. But not all residents are reacting with outrage, with some downplaying the comments made by the Trump administration.

items.title: ‘That is so cool’ : Video of lynx captured in northwestern Ontario draws attention
items.summary_auto: The internet loves a cat video - and a wildlife encounter captured on film in northwestern Ontario this January is no exception. The footage features a group of lynx, including three kittens.

items.title: London Drugs in heart of Vancouver's Downtown Eastside to close on Feb. 1
items.summary_auto: The decision to close the location in the Woodwards Building, which has been open since 2009 and in the neighbourhood since 1945, was not taken lightly, according to London Drugs President and COO Clint Mahlman.

items.title: Glenn Hall, whose NHL goalie starts streak may never be broken, dies at age 94
items.summary_auto: Glenn Hall, a Hockey Hall of Famer whose streak of 502 starts as a goaltender remains an NHL record, has died. He was 94.

items.title: Vancouver Symphony Orchestra to end use of NDAs for sexual misconduct cases
items.summary_auto: The Vancouver Symphony Orchestra will end the use of non-disclosure agreements in cases involving sexual misconduct following backlash over its response to a musician who had gone public with sexual assault allegations.

items.title: People regained weight, worsened heart health after stopping weight loss drugs: review
items.summary_auto: When people who are overweight and obese stopped taking their weight-loss medications they regained weight faster than those who stopped a diet or exercise program, a new review of studies finds.

items.title: With Carney headed to China for trade talks, what’s in it for B.C.?
items.summary_auto: As Prime Minister Mark Carney prepares for a trade trip to China, British Columbian officials believe he could open the door to new markets for local industry.

items.title: Trump suspends U.S. support for 66 international organizations
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump on Wednesday signed an executive order suspending U.S. support for 66 organizations, agencies and commissions following his instructions for his administration to review participation in and funding for all international organizations, including those affiliated with the United Nations, according to a White House statement on social media.

items.title: Rink explosion in Alta. town last month caused by mechanical failure: investigation
items.summary_auto: A propane leak from Zamboni ice machine, not human error, caused blast that badly damaged recreation centre in Taber, Alta.

items.title: Brigitte Bardot’s funeral draws crowd in small French town
items.summary_auto: Residents and admirers applauded the funeral convoy as Brigitte Bardot's coffin was being carried through the narrow streets of Saint-Tropez. Once one of the world's most photographed women, she had long called the French Riviera resort her refuge from the celebrity that made her a household name.

items.title: Quebec’s photo radars generated record-breaking $133M in fines in 2025
items.summary_auto: The province’s Justice Ministry says mobile photo radars, which can be moved from one site to another, brought in nearly $97 million of the total amount. Some spots seem to be more lucrative than others.

items.title: Lawyer says Coquitlam, B.C., RCMP officer should be dismissed for sexist, racist group chat comments
items.summary_auto: Coquitlam RCMP Const. Mersad Mesbah testified on his own behalf at a hearing Wednesday for whether he should be dismissed from the police force for derogatory comments he made in group chats with other officers.

items.title: Netflix seemingly confirms there is no Stranger Things 'secret episode'
items.summary_auto: Netflix has ostensibly confirmed there is no “secret” Stranger Things episode set for release tonight, responding to fan speculation around a proposed finale unofficially dubbed “Conformity Gate.”

items.title: Alberta's measles case count topped 2,000 last year, and the outbreak is not over yet
items.summary_auto: Alberta's measles outbreaks sparked more than 2,000 cases of the highly infectious illness in 2025, and while transmission has dropped dramatically, experts warn the virus remains a threat in the year ahead.

items.title: Ottawa mother convicted in death of girl born on plane gets 10 years in prison
items.summary_auto: In 2020, a woman failed to take her five-year-old daughter to see a doctor for six days before the girl died in her bedroom from an untreated bladder rupture. She has now been sentenced to 10 years in prison, minus half a year already spent in custody.

items.title: Mother convicted in death of girl born on plane gets 10 years in prison
items.summary_auto: In 2020, a woman failed to take her five-year-old daughter to see a doctor for six days before the girl died in her bedroom from an untreated bladder rupture. She has now been sentenced to 10 years in prison, minus half a year already spent in custody.

items.title: Carter George hopes to inspire Thunder Bay, Ont.'s next crop of NHL talent
items.summary_auto: Thunder Bay has long been known as a hockey hotbed, sending dozens of local players to the National Hockey League, and even a pair of players to the Hockey Hall of Fame. Yet, when it comes to the annual World Junior Ice Hockey Championships, Thunder Bay’s representation is comparatively low.

items.title: Like many Ukrainians, she fled war for Quebec. Now, she fears they can’t stay
items.summary_auto: The future of many Ukrainians living in Quebec is in limbo after the provincial government cancelled a program that offered a pathway to permanent residency. Now, some are urging the government to create a special immigration program to allow them to stay.
